newsitem.title: USA: Exocell says settles suit against Boehringer.
newsitem.headline: Exocell says settles suit against Boehringer.

text.p: Exocell Inc said Monday it had settled a lawsuit against Boehringer Mannheim GMbH over monoclonal antibodies and the case had been dismissed.
Exocell said it sued the Mannheim, Germany,-based company in a Pennsylvania state court in April 1996, alleging that certain statements filed in a Boehringer patent application were false.
According to Exocell, Boehringer Mannhaim said in its application that Exocell's A717 monoclonal antibodies did not recognize glycated albumin formed in the body.
Under the settlement, Exocell, said Boehringer "acknowledges and accepts" that the antibodies react with glycated albumin formed in the body.
"This settlement and our issued patents solidify our proprietary position for A717 in the clinical and commercial arena," said Margo Cohen, Exocell president and chief scientific officer.
Exocell is a biomedical company that is developing products for diabetes and related complications.
Boeringher is a commercial leader in diabetes management products.
